citeinfo.title: Data release: Exploring the exceptional performance of a deep learning stream temperature model and the value of streamflow data
citeinfo.geoform: parent data item for released data products

descript.abstract:
This data release provides all data and code used in Rahmani et al. 2020. Briefly, this project used the CAMELS dataset as a test case for temperature prediction using deep learning methods. XX
The data are organized into these items:

  1. Spatial Information - Basin polygons and pour points for 118 river basins used in this study
  2. Observations - Water temperature observations and flow observations for the 118 river reaches used in this study
  3. Model Inputs - Model inputs, including basin characteristics and weather drivers.
  4. Models - Code and configuration for stream temperature models.
  5. Model Predictions - Predictions of water temperature
  6. Model Evaluation - Performance of models

    7. This research was funded by the USGS, XX.
descript.purpose: Decision support, limnological research, and fish habitat.

spdom.descgeog: River reach polylines as defined by the XX.

idinfo.useconst: These data are subject to change and are not citable until reviewed and approved for official publication by the USGS
idinfo.datacred: This study was funded by the Department of the Interior Northeast Climate Adaptation Science Center, the United States Geological Survey National Climate This research used resources of the Core Science Analytics and Synthesis Advanced Research Computing program at the U.S. Geological Survey.
idinfo.native: Multiple computer systems were used to generate these data, including linux, OSX. The open source languages R and Python were used on all systems. XX

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted.

horizpa.horizpar: A formal accuracy assessment of the horizontal positional information in the dataset was not conducted.

vertacc.vertaccr: A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the dataset was not conducted.

procstep.procdesc: At the core of the modeling framework is a coupled hydrologic-thermodynamic model that uses inputs of reach-specific properties and local meteorology to estimate flow and water temperature. Our chosen model is the open source, Precipitation Runoff Modeling System (PRMS) with the coupled Stream Network Temperature Model (SNTemp) version XX. PRMS-SNTemp is a ...XX. We used PRMS-SNTemp to simulate stream flow and temperature for the period of record...XX.

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.
